problem.tex: Take a bounded domain $\Omega$. Let $\{e_n\}_{n=1}^\infty$ be an orthonormal basis of $L^2(\Omega)$. For $z,w\in\Omega$, show \[K(z,w)=\sum_{n=1}^\infty e_n(z)\overline{e_n(w)}.\] Justify that this formulation is independent of choice of basis and show that $K(z,z)>0$ for any $z\in\Omega$.

solution.tex: Take the holomorphic (in $z$) function $K(z,w)$ and express it with respect to the basis. To do this, recall $K(z,w)=R_w(z)$ for a holomorphic $L^2$ function $R_w$. \[R_w=\sum_{n=1}^\infty\langle R_w,e_n\rangle e_n=\sum_{n=1}^\infty\overline{\langle e_n,R_w\rangle}e_n.\] Recall the point of obtaining $R_w$ in the first place; it is the Riesz representation of the evaluation functional $L_w$. That is, $\langle e_n,R_w\rangle=e_n(w)$. Thus \[R_w=\sum_{n=1}^\infty\overline{e_n(w)}e_n.\] Plugging in $z$ to this function gives \[K(z,w)=R_w(z)=\sum_{n=1}^\infty\overline{e_n(w)}e_n(z)=\sum_{n=1}^\infty e_n(z)\overline{e_n(w)}.\] The formula holds regardless of choice of basis because it was obtained from the projection property, which holds for any basis, and from the properties of $K$, which were derived without the use of bases. Using the formula, \[K(z,z)=\sum_{n=1}^\infty|e_n(z)|^2\geq0.\] Moreover, there must be some $n$ for which $e_n(z)\neq0$ because $1$ is a holomorphic $L^2$ function on $\Omega$ and \[1=\sum_{n=1}^\infty\langle 1,e_n\rangle e_n.\] In order for this equality to hold at $z$, not all the $e_n$ can vanish at $z$. Thus $K(z,z)>0$.
